title: Fasting Regimen
content: Switching from 7-day fasting to 3-days fasting has been observed to be easier, not just because they are shorter, but there is less feeling of 'dragging'. Exercise tolerance is higher since there is not the same degree of glycogen depletion. The implications to this is that there won't have to dial back the volume/intensity of workouts multiple times per year.

title: Ketone Measuring Devices
content: There are a few different ketone checking devices: Blood testing—Precision Xtra (more accurate at lower levels), Keto-Mojo (runs 'a little high' at lower levels). Breath testing—A new breath device for measuring acetone is being tested (not commercially available yet). Historically, breathe acetone and blood ketone levels have not been very correlated.

title: Zero-Calorie Sweeteners and Ketone Production
content: Zero-calorie sweeteners can impair the ability to make ketones. This was observed when feeling unwell after chewing gum and occasionally having a diet soda while fasting, and checking blood ketones levels.

title: Continuous Insulin Monitor
content: A continuous insulin monitor is unlikely to be developed soon. Insulin is a much more complicated thing to measure than glucose, lactate, beta-hydroxybutyrate, hemoglobin, even cholesterol, or triglyceride.

title: Exogenous Ketones
content: During a fast, it is not recommended to ingest exogenous ketones. One thing you are trying to accomplish with a fast is autophagy, and exogenous ketones are a source of energy which would probably impair autophagy from happening. Three things that signal autophagy to happen are: Low ATP, Low mTOR, and a reduction in the cytosolic pool of acetyl-CoA.

title: Exogenous Ketones and Blood Glucose Levels
content: Ingesting ketones can drive down blood glucose levels. This could be because ketones elicit insulin, which then drives blood glucose levels down. Another possible factor is that the body may sense that with a rise of BHB, you have more energy substrate (ATP) so therefore it down regulates your blood glucose.

title: Fasting and Blood Glucose Levels
content: Several days into a fast, BHB is about ~4 mmol and blood glucose is about 3 to 4 mmol. The sum being 7-8 mmol. After about 24 hours of fasting, BHB levels are usually between 0.5-1.0 mmol.

title: Tips for Multi-day Fasting
content: Start with baby steps, know you can end it whenever you need to. Fast with others to be able to support each other. Have a plan for when you know it will be tough. Have something to look forward to. Start with baby steps, first get some experience with time-restricted eating then try to elongate the fasting window to 24 hours, then many 36 hours, then 48 and keep progressing from there.

title: BHB Levels, Glucose Levels, and Autophagy
content: Having high ketones is consistent with being in a state of autophagy. The question is whether it's the actual BHB itself that is a signal for autophagy, or if it's the energetic state that produces BHB the signal for autophagy.

title: Measuring Blood Insulin vs Blood Glucose
content: Measuring blood insulin is much harder than blood glucose due to the complexity of the chemical reaction. With glucose and BHB, you take the drop of whole blood and don't have to separate plasma from serum. With more complicated assays like insulin, it has to go through multiple iterations of washing the reagent away, putting another antibody on, and so on.

title: Exercise for Longevity
content: Exercise for longevity is less time consuming that exercise for performance. A framework for exercise includes stability, strength, aerobic efficiency, and anaerobic performance. The amount of time spent on each component varies by individual. It's suggested to try to exercise every single day.

title: Strength Training
content: Work on strength training for 10 min per day, or at least a dedicated hour a week. You could really efficiently get some good work done in three, one-hour sessions in a week.

title: Aerobic Efficiency
content: The minimum effective dose if you’re starting from nowhere is probably two hours a week. If you have a reasonable base of fitness, probably three hours per week is better.

title: Anaerobic Work
content: You don’t need much of this. And it’s very easy to incorporate into regular activity.

title: Exercise for Aging Well
content: Exercising towards aging well and being able to physically do the things that matter to you as you get older is important. Once people enter that seventh and eighth decade, if they haven’t done a lot of consistent preparatory work in the decades prior, it’s alarming how quickly things go south. The goal is to mitigate that risk.
